moves.1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Bb5 a6: It might look liek Black has adequate defense here, but the Black Square Bishop is over worked defending two pieces. Only one will survive.
moves.12. Bxf6: If Black's White Square Bishop takes the Knight, White's Bishop takes the Pawn on g attacking the Rook and then escapes. If Black takes the Bishop he loses the Pawn on c.
He spent a lot of moves building his little fortress and now has weakened it?
moves.22. Qd6 Qe6: Trading Queens was not a winner for Black, but losing a Pawn is not better.
moves.23. Qxc5 Rfd8: There is a bit of danger that the White Queen might have to struggle to escape, so she needs to get back quickly now.
moves.24. Qa5: Looks like it will be a successful sortie that won a Pawn with a safe retreat back behind friendly lines.
That Pawn on d is a tempting target once he moves that Rook from defending it, but I must be careful as long as he has that Black-Square Bishop that could pin the Knight there.
moves.34. Nh4 Rfg8 35. Nhxg6 Bd6 36. Nh4 Rdf8: The thing I have been watchful of is the two Bishops he has. I have been careful not to give them an open diagonal toward my King's side. Now he has traded one Bishop, so I will be less worried about the other. I also may go after that pawn on d now that the dangerous Bishop is gone.
moves.38. fxe5 Bc6 39. Rg3+: SInce I have a material advantage now, I only need to worry about some clever attack by his Rooks and Bishop. I can force trades to eliminate his offensive capabilities which will leave me to methodically drive forward to a win.
I had intended to move the Pawn on g to g4 in order to trap his Bishop, but he saved me the trouble.
moves.48. Rd2 Bxc2 49. Rxc2: Black resigned with the quip: "I finally got one of your Pawns". I hadn't actually though about it, but that was the first Whie Pawn taken. What an unusual game!
